resolution.description: A fix for this issue is checked into the tree and tested.
resolution.name: Fixed

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.
status.name: Resolved

mrkn commented on issue #3760: ARROW-4684: [Python] Debug Cython test failure
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/3760#issuecomment-467670340
 
 
   The reason why the test failed is `-fno-plt` option is not supported by gcc version 5.
   Upgrading gcc can resolve this issue.
 
----------------------------------------------------------------
This is an automated message from the Apache Git Service.
To respond to the message, please log on GitHub and use the
URL above to go to the specific comment.

users@infra.apache.org

wesm commented on issue #3760: ARROW-4684: [Python] Debug Cython test failure
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/3760#issuecomment-467711776
 
 
   I wonder why `-fno-plt` is getting introduced suddenly. We can resolve the issue by using the `gcc_linux-64` and `gxx_linux-64` compiler toolchain packages. But then we aren't using gcc 5.4

pitrou commented on issue #3760: ARROW-4684: [Python] Debug Cython test failure
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/3760#issuecomment-467892966
 
 
   Hmm, silencing the `test_cython` error wasn't enough. Then it fails installing `pickle5`:
   https://travis-ci.org/apache/arrow/jobs/499285776#L4033
   
   In any case, it seems it's going to be fixed in conda-forge:
   https://gitter.im/conda-forge/conda-forge.github.io?at=5c769889608c6f373631487f
   
   > Jonathan J. Helmus
   @jjhelmus
   15:02
   @pitrou The Python packages in defaults uses generic flags unless an environment variable is set by the compiler activation script. I'll look at porting that patch over to conda-forge.

issuetype.description: A problem which impairs or prevents the functions of the product.
issuetype.name: Bug

fields.description:
It seems we're starting to get Travis-CI failures in {{test_cython.py}}. Example here:
{code}
----------------------------- Captured stdout call -----------------------------
Compiling pyarrow_cython_example.pyx because it changed.
[1/1] Cythonizing pyarrow_cython_example.pyx
running build_ext
building 'pyarrow_cython_example' extension
creating build
creating build/temp.linux-x86_64-2.7
gcc -fno-strict-aliasing -march=nocona -mtune=haswell -ftree-vectorize -fPIC -fstack-protector-strong -fno-plt -O3 -pipe -fdebug-prefix-map=${SRC_DIR}=/usr/local/src/conda/${PKG_NAME}-${PKG_VERSION} -fdebug-prefix-map=${PREFIX}=/usr/local/src/conda-prefix -DNDEBUG -fwrapv -O3 -Wall -Wstrict-prototypes -fPIC -I/home/travis/build/apache/arrow/pyarrow-test-2.7/lib/python2.7/site-packages/numpy/core/include -I/home/travis/build/apache/arrow/python/pyarrow/include -I/home/travis/build/apache/arrow/pyarrow-test-2.7/include/python2.7 -c pyarrow_cython_example.cpp -o build/temp.linux-x86_64-2.7/pyarrow_cython_example.o -std=c++11
----------------------------- Captured stderr call -----------------------------
gcc: error: unrecognized command line option '-fno-plt'
error: command 'gcc' failed with exit status 1
{code}

(from https://travis-ci.org/apache/arrow/jobs/498722197)

I'm afraid this looks like a conda-forge toolchain issue :-(

comments.body: Yes, this is a toolchain issue. conda-forge add {{-fno-plt}} to CXXFLAGS which is only supported on newer gcc versions. I can take care of this in my build system refactor: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/3688
Where is this CXXFLAGS coming from, `conda activate`?
Yes, it's conda injecting a lot of undesirable stuff :-/
Could we disable this single test until it's resolved?
Unfortunately it's not enough, see PR.
This was fixed in conda-forge by https://github.com/conda-forge/python-feedstock/pull/249 . The CI job is green now.
